G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The increased distance, travel time, anxiety, and interference with Sophie’s schooling and activities constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the 2021 Judgment, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) and Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This is a Complaint for Modification brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s equitable powers, seeking modification of an existing custody and parenting-time judgment relating to the minor child of the parties.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The increased distance, travel time, anxiety, and interference with Sophie’s schooling and activities constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the 2021 Judgment, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) and Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn deals with the impact of domestic violence on custody determinations and the need for explicit findings about family violence under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related provisions. It does not address relocation, increased distance, travel time, or interference with schooling/activities as a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Using Vaughn to support that specific change‑in‑circumstances proposition stretches the case beyond its subject matter and holding.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking."

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The increased distance, travel time, anxiety, and interference with Sophie’s schooling and activities constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the 2021 Judgment, within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) and Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss material and substantial changes in circumstances, relocation impacts, travel time, or interference with schooling under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Instead, it addresses initial custody determinations under § 31 and reiterates that custody decisions must be based on the child’s best interests, not as punishment for a parent’s misconduct. It therefore does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about increased distance and related burdens constituting a material change in circumstances.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 509\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 509–510 (2013); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–844 (2003).
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 509\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly distinguishes between standards for modifying custody versus child support under G.L. c. 208, § 28. It explains that after the 1993 amendment, § 28 applies the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus best-interests standard to custody modifications, while a different ‘inconsistency’ standard governs child support modifications. Thus, Morales is proper authority for the proposition that Massachusetts custody/parenting-time orders may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 509\u.relevant_excerpt: “Prior to its amendment in 1993… § 28 provided that the material and substantial change standard was the correct standard for determining whether to modify a custody judgment or a child support order… The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders. Compare § 28… (court may modify prior judgment as to ‘the care and custody of the minor children’ on finding that occurrence of a ‘material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties’ and best interests of children make modification necessary)…”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or parenting-time order may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 28; Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 509–510 (2013); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843–844 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.support_reasoning: This case is explicitly about an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not a modification proceeding. The court mentions the “substantial change in circumstances” standard only in describing G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and then declines to apply it, holding that the case was tried as an original custody matter. The opinion therefore does not establish or apply the two-part modification test (material and substantial change plus best interests) described in the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The best interests of the child standard is paramount and requires consideration of the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, including continuity, stability, and the minimization of conflict and stress.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The best interests of the child standard is paramount and requires consideration of the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, including continuity, stability, and the minimization of conflict and stress.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the “central question” as Hugo’s best interests and applies that standard in a holistic way, focusing on his emotional, physical, and developmental needs and weighing continuity and stability against the harms and benefits of a change in placement. The court repeatedly discusses the importance of stability, the impact of transitions and trauma, the need to minimize developmental deficits, and the comparative ability of each placement to provide a consistent, predictable, and supportive environment, thereby supporting the proposition’s articulation of the best‑interests standard.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”}

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: The law recognizes that substantial changes in residence or distance between households, even where the child’s primary residence does not change, can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification of parenting time. See, e.g., Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183–184 (2006); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–262 (2001); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868–869 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, where a parent with joint physical and legal custody sought to move the children out of Massachusetts. The opinion discusses when a relocation constitutes a substantial change in circumstances in the context of ALI Principles § 2.17, but it does so in terms of removal and the best-interests standard, not in the context of a modification of parenting time where the child’s primary residence remains the same. It does not hold that substantial changes in residence or distance between households, absent a change of the child’s primary residence, constitute a material change justifying modification of parenting time; rather, it frames relocation as potentially a “substantial change” when it significantly impairs the exercise of parental responsibilities, in the removal context.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances … only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce] …’ … It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities… .”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–262 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The law recognizes that substantial changes in residence or distance between households, even where the child’s primary residence does not change, can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification of parenting time. See, e.g., Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183–184 (2006); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–262 (2001); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868–869 (2006).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a custodial parent’s proposed out-of-state relocation and related temporary orders can justify a permanent change in physical custody. It does not hold or discuss that substantial changes in residence or distance between households (where primary residence remains the same) may constitute a material change in circumstances for modifying parenting time. Instead, the court explicitly rejects using the relocation itself or the court-imposed temporary change in where the child spends weekdays as the material change supporting custody modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868–869 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: The law recognizes that substantial changes in residence or distance between households, even where the child’s primary residence does not change, can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification of parenting time. See, e.g., Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183–184 (2006); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261–262 (2001); Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 868–869 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a removal request and the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test, not with modification of parenting time based on increased distance or changes in residence where the child’s primary residence remains the same. Its discussion of ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ under G.L. c. 208, § 28 focuses on the custodial parent’s remarriage as a post‑judgment change, not on geographic distance or relocation within a parenting-time framework. It therefore does not establish or apply the specific principle that substantial changes in distance between households, absent a change in primary residence, justify modification of parenting time.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… ‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred….’ Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances….”

Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.raw_text: Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326, 333–334 (2007)
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.proposition: Massachusetts courts regularly recognize that parenting-time orders should be tailored to the realities of the parties’ circumstances and to the evolving needs of the child, and should be modified where necessary to protect the child’s best interests. See, e.g., Morales, 464 Mass. at 510–511; Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326, 333–334 (2007); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–404 (1981).
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the phrase “parenting-time orders,” but it is a removal/parenting-schedule case where the Appeals Court reiterates that the child’s best interests must be determined by considering all relevant interests (custodial parent, noncustodial parent, and child) and vacates the judgment for not properly doing so. The court emphasizes that custody/visitation determinations must account for the realities of the parties’ circumstances (including the custodial parent’s quality of life) and remands for further proceedings to reassess what arrangement is in the child’s best interests, which is consistent with the cited proposition about tailoring and modifying parenting time in light of evolving needs and best interests.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.relevant_excerpt: “‘[B]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’ … These ultimate findings, or conclusions, do not adequately reflect consideration of each of the interests — those of the mother, as well as the father and the child — that inform the best interests determination. … We vacate the judgment and remand this matter for further hearing so that findings may be made, consistent with this opinion, as to all of the relevant interests.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts courts regularly recognize that parenting-time orders should be tailored to the realities of the parties’ circumstances and to the evolving needs of the child, and should be modified where necessary to protect the child’s best interests. See, e.g., Morales, 464 Mass. at 510–511; Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326, 333–334 (2007); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–404 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies the child’s “best interests” standard to both custody and visitation and affirms that visitation (parenting time) may be limited in light of the specific circumstances and parental conflict. In section 3, the court upholds a reduction of the father’s visitation because, given “the circumstances and the personalities involved,” such a reduction was justified to promote the children’s best interests and maintain their welfare, reflecting tailoring of parenting time to the realities of the case and the children’s needs. While the case discusses modification in the context of moving from a temporary to a final order, it squarely recognizes that parenting-time arrangements may be adjusted as necessary to protect the children’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–152 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: Maintaining the current midweek overnight arrangement in the face of Father’s significant move would effectively transform an arrangement that once was in the child’s best interests into one that is unduly burdensome and contrary to her welfare, which is precisely the kind of changed circumstance that justifies modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related authority. See, e.g., Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595–596; Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 151–152 (2015).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: Murray v. Super is a removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, analyzing the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best interests framework for an out‑of‑state move by a primary physical custodian. It does not involve or discuss modification of an existing parenting schedule under G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it address a situation where a parent’s relocation makes an existing midweek overnight schedule unduly burdensome. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific § 28 “changed circumstances” proposition asserted.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… and Hale… We address each prong in turn.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: To the extent necessary, Mother also invokes the Court’s authority under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to make such orders in equity as justice and the best interests of the child require.
